newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore non-oil exports fall in September.
newsitem.headline: Singapore non-oil exports fall in September.

text.p: Singapore's non-oil exports fell 6.2 percent year-on-year in nominal terms in September due to a slowdown in the worldwide electronics industry, the Trade Development Board (TDB) said on Monday.
Total non-oil domestic exports totalled Singapore $7.31 billion (US$5.18 billion) last month.
In August, the city-state's non-oil domestic exports fell 6.3 percent to S$7.01 billion.
A Reuter poll of 12 Singapore-based economists had predicted a nominal year-on-year fall of 3.4 percent in September.
A TDB statement said non-oil exports to the United States increased marginally by 1.2 percent to S$2.3 billion in September, but exports to Europe, Japan and neighbouring Malaysia all fell.
"Non-oil domestic exports declined by 6.2 percent due to the continued sluggishness in global electronics demand," the statement said.
Electronics, computers and related products account for about half Singapore's total industrial production and almost 60 percent of its non-oil exports.
In real terms, non-oil exports fell 2.5 percent in September to S$9.29 billion after falling 2.8 percent in August.
The biggest percentage fall in exports was seen for telecommunication equipment, which registered a 23.7 percent year-on-year fall in September.
Exports of electrical machinery and electronic valves also fell sharply, by 16.2 percent and 11.7 percent respectively.
Analysts said the figures confirmed their generally pessimistic view of the prospects for the Singapore economy as a whole for 1996.

P.K. Basu, regional economist at UBS in Singapore, said the export data reinforced his view that the city-state's gross domestic product (GDP) was likely to grow by about 5.7 percent in 1996, after 8.8 percent in 1995 and 10.2 percent in 1994.

Paul Schymyck, head of research at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, who had expected the September export figures to show a rebound from the slump in August, said he would now consider revising downwards his forecast for Singapore's 1996 growth.
"It is worse than expected," he said. "I think it would lead to a further reduction of our (growth) forecast for the year by perhaps 0.5 percent to close to six percent."
